name: 1579_C. Ticks
description:
Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered field of size n × m. Initially, all cells of the field are white.

Let us denote the cell with coordinates i vertically and j horizontally by (i, j). The upper left cell will be referred to as (1, 1) and the lower right cell as (n, m).

Casimir draws ticks of different sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn as follows: 

  1. First, the center cell (i, j) is painted black. 
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also painted black. 
  3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for all h between 0 and d are painted. In particular, a tick consists of 2d + 1 black cells. 



An already painted cell will remain black if painted again. Below you can find an example of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You are given a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field came about after he drew some (possibly 0) ticks on it. The ticks could be of different sizes, but the size of each tick is at least k (that is, d ≥ k for all the ticks).

Determine whether this field can indeed be obtained by drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

prompt:
Casimir possesses a rectangular sheet featuring a checkered zone with dimensions n × m. At the outset, every cell within the region is white.

Let's assign labels to the cell using vertical coordinate i and horizontal coordinate j as (i, j). The cell situated at the top left will be marked (1, 1), and the cell at the bottom right will be marked (n, m).

Casimir sketches ticks of various sizes on the area. A tick of size d (d > 0) centered in cell (i, j) is created in the following manner:

1. Initially, the cell at the center (i, j) receives a black paint. The painting of this central cell is the first step in creating the tick. 
2. Subsequently, exactly d cells in the top-left diagonal to the center and exactly d cells in the top-right diagonal to the center are also turned black. 
3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for every h ranging from 0 to d are painted. Specifically, a tick contains a total of 2d + 1 black cells.

A cell that's already painted will remain black if repainted. Below you can see an illustration of the 4 × 9 grid, showcasing two ticks with sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You receive a description of a checkered area sized n × m. Casimir states that this area is a result of him drawing several ticks on it. The ticks might vary in sizes, but each tick size is at least k (meaning d ≥ k for every tick).

Determine whether this area can genuinely be composed by sketching a few (potentially none) ticks with sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the given checkered area can be composed of ticks of a specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid representation with '*' for painted cells and '.' for unpainted cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, "YES" if the grid can be formed by ticks, otherwise "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a boolean grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        can_be_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check for possible tick centers from bottom to top
        for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with center at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1
                    size -= 1  # Adjust size to the maximum possible

                    if size >= k:
                        # Mark the cells of the tick
                        for h in range(size + 1):
                            can_be_tick[i - h][j - h] = True
                            can_be_tick[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid can be part of a tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_tick[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Input interface
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid representation with '*' for painted cells and '.' for unpainted cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, "YES" if the grid can be formed by ticks, "NO" otherwise.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a boolean grid to mark cells that can be part of a valid tick
        can_be_part_of_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell if it can be the center of a tick of size at least k
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with center at (i, j)
                    valid_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    if valid_tick:
                        # Mark the cells of this tick as valid
                        for d in range(k + 1):
                            can_be_part_of_tick[i - d][j - d] = True
                            can_be_part_of_tick[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid can be part of a valid tick
        possible = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_part_of_tick[i][j]:
                    possible = False
                    break
            if not possible:
                break

        results.append("YES" if possible else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()

    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = data[index + 1:index + 1 + n]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
        index += n + 1

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n: Number of rows in the grid.
            - m: Number of columns in the grid.
            - k: Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid: A list of strings representing the grid.

    Returns:
        A list of strings, each being "YES" or "NO" for the corresponding test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_tick_center = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick of size at least k
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    valid_tick = True
                    # Check top-left diagonal
                    for h in range(1, k + 1):
                        if grid[i - h][j - h] != '*':
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    # Check top-right diagonal
                    if valid_tick:
                        for h in range(1, k + 1):
                            if grid[i - h][j + h] != '*':
                                valid_tick = False
                                break
                    # Mark the center if a valid tick is found
                    if valid_tick:
                        can_be_tick_center[i][j] = True

        # Check if all '*' can be part of a tick
        possible = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if this '*' can be part of a tick
                    part_of_tick = False
                    # Check if it can be a center or part of a tick
                    if can_be_tick_center[i][j]:
                        part_of_tick = True
                    else:
                        # Check if it can be part of a tick centered below
                        for d in range(1, min(i + 1, j + 1, m - j)):
                            if i + d < n and can_be_tick_center[i + d][j]:
                                part_of_tick = True
                                break
                    if not part_of_tick:
                        possible = False
                        break
            if not possible:
                break

        results.append("YES" if possible else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions, minimum tick size, and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_center = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    if is_valid_tick_center(i, j, n, m, k, grid):
                        can_be_center[i][j] = True

        # Verify if all painted cells can be part of a tick
        if all_painted_cells_covered(n, m, grid, can_be_center):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

def is_valid_tick_center(i: int, j: int, n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str]) -> bool:
    """Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center.

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center cell.
        j (int): Column index of the center cell.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        grid (List[str]): Grid data.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a valid tick can be formed, False otherwise.
    """
    # Check top-left diagonal
    for h in range(1, k + 1):
        if i - h < 0 or j - h < 0 or grid[i - h][j - h] != '*':
            return False

    # Check top-right diagonal
    for h in range(1, k + 1):
        if i - h < 0 or j + h >= m or grid[i - h][j + h] != '*':
            return False

    return True

def all_painted_cells_covered(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], can_be_center: List[List[bool]]) -> bool:
    """Verify if all painted cells can be part of a tick.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): Grid data.
        can_be_center (List[List[bool]]): 2D list indicating if a cell can be the center of a tick.

    Returns:
        bool: True if all painted cells are covered by ticks, False otherwise.
    """
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_center[i][j]:
                return False
    return True

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size at least k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                                grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            marked[i - h][j - h] = True
                            marked[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Check if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_tick_center = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick of size at least k
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check top-left diagonal
                    valid_top_left = all(grid[i - h][j - h] == '*' for h in range(1, k + 1))
                    # Check top-right diagonal
                    valid_top_right = all(grid[i - h][j + h] == '*' for h in range(1, k + 1))
                    
                    if valid_top_left and valid_top_right:
                        can_be_tick_center[i][j] = True
                        # Mark cells in the diagonals as part of a tick
                        for h in range(k + 1):
                            can_be_tick_center[i - h][j - h] = True
                            can_be_tick_center[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Check if all '*' cells can be part of a tick
        is_possible = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_tick_center[i][j]:
                    is_possible = False
                    break
            if not is_possible:
                break

        results.append("YES" if is_possible else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results ('YES' or 'NO') for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a copy of the grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked_grid = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with center at (i, j)
                    can_form_tick = True
                    for h in range(1, k + 1):
                        if i - h < 0 or j - h < 0 or j + h >= m:
                            can_form_tick = False
                            break
                        if grid[i - h][j - h] != '*' or grid[i - h][j + h] != '*':
                            can_form_tick = False
                            break

                    if can_form_tick:
                        # Mark the cells that are part of the tick
                        for h in range(k + 1):
                            marked_grid[i - h][j - h] = True
                            marked_grid[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Check if all '*' in the grid can be part of a tick
        is_valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked_grid[i][j]:
                    is_valid = False
                    break
            if not is_valid:
                break

        results.append('YES' if is_valid else 'NO')

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be composed of ticks of a minimum size.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n: Number of rows in the grid.
            - m: Number of columns in the grid.
            - k: Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid: A list of strings representing the grid.

    Returns:
        A list of strings, each being "YES" or "NO" for the corresponding test case.
    """
    def is_valid_tick_center(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str], i: int, j: int) -> bool:
        """Check if a cell can be the center of a valid tick of size at least k."""
        size = 0
        while True:
            if i - size < 0 or j - size < 0 or j + size >= m:
                break
            if grid[i - size][j - size] != '*' or grid[i - size][j + size] != '*':
                break
            size += 1
        return size > k

    def can_form_ticks_for_case(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str]) -> str:
        """Check if the grid can be formed by ticks of size at least k."""
        # Create a copy of the grid to mark used cells
        used = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Traverse the grid from bottom to top
        for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not used[i][j]:
                    if is_valid_tick_center(n, m, k, grid, i, j):
                        # Mark the cells of the tick as used
                        size = 0
                        while True:
                            if i - size < 0 or j - size < 0 or j + size >= m:
                                break
                            if grid[i - size][j - size] != '*' or grid[i - size][j + size] != '*':
                                break
                            used[i - size][j - size] = True
                            used[i - size][j + size] = True
                            size += 1
                    else:
                        return "NO"
        return "YES"

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        result = can_form_ticks_for_case(n, m, k, grid)
        results.append(result)
    
    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a grid can be composed of ticks of a minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_center = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if the cell can be the center of a tick of size at least k
                    valid_tick = True
                    for h in range(1, k + 1):
                        if grid[i - h][j - h] != '*' or grid[i - h][j + h] != '*':
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    if valid_tick:
                        can_be_center[i][j] = True

        # Mark cells that can be part of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if can_be_center[i][j]:
                    for h in range(k + 1):
                        grid[i - h] = grid[i - h][:j - h] + '*' + grid[i - h][j - h + 1:]
                        grid[i - h] = grid[i - h][:j + h] + '*' + grid[i - h][j + h + 1:]

        # Check if all '*' cells can be part of a tick
        possible = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_center[i][j]:
                    possible = False
                    break
            if not possible:
                break

        results.append("YES" if possible else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if the given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be centered at (i, j)
                    if can_form_tick(i, j, k, n, m, grid, marked):
                        mark_tick(i, j, k, n, m, marked)

        # Check if all '*' cells are marked
        if all(grid[i][j] == '.' or marked[i][j] for i in range(n) for j in range(m)):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

def can_form_tick(i: int, j: int, k: int, n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], marked: List[List[bool]]) -> bool:
    """Checks if a tick of size k can be formed centered at (i, j).

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center.
        j (int): Column index of the center.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid representation.
        marked (List[List[bool]]): Grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a tick can be formed, False otherwise.
    """
    if i < k or j < k or j + k >= m:
        return False

    for h in range(1, k + 1):
        if grid[i - h][j - h] != '*' or grid[i - h][j + h] != '*':
            return False

    return True

def mark_tick(i: int, j: int, k: int, n: int, m: int, marked: List[List[bool]]) -> None:
    """Marks the cells of a tick centered at (i, j) with size k.

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center.
        j (int): Column index of the center.
        k (int): Size of the tick.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        marked (List[List[bool]]): Grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick.
    """
    marked[i][j] = True
    for h in range(1, k + 1):
        marked[i - h][j - h] = True
        marked[i - h][j + h] = True

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.
